description.narrative: Following the success of a safe motherhood project in the Mulanje mission area, SRUN proposes to replicate the project in the H. Parker mission hospital health area in Zomba. Amongst other factors, the area is characterized with late attendance of antenatal clinics by women. According to June, July August 2014 data, out of all the ANC mothers who came for initial visit only 1 came in the first trimester. All the women that reported in labour ward they were already in active stage of labour. The area has ineffective transport modes to reach the facility. H. Parker also reports high prevalence of complications where about 30% of the clients were referred to Zomba central in the last 3 months. There is high prevalence of teenage pregnancies where 25% of all the pregnant women attending ANC were teenagers. It was also noted that poor staff attitude towards patients/clients was another major reason for community members not accessing services at the facility ,hence people opting to seek medical care somewhere else, which may not be ideal like delivering at TBAs (because only 10 women delivered at the facility in 3 months) and hence resulting in poor maternal and neonatal outcomes.

This project focuses on promoting health facility access and safe motherhood in Malawi. The interventions are addressing adverse maternal and child health outcomes and aim to lower maternal and neonatal deaths.
The proposed project envisions women that are confident and supported by men, church and community structures to easily access quality sexual and reproductive health services. The project aims to attain sustained comprehensive integrated SRHR services that are accessible, acceptable,

title.narrative: Number of partner-projects showing improved health proxy indicators amongst vulnerable groupsBH&H--A

Number of partners who work in close collaboration with relevant change agents and capacitate them to play a leading and constructiverole in addressing the silence and stigma around disability, HIV and SRHR in a gender sensitive manner BH&H--A
Number of partners with improved access to basic health and health-related services for vulnerable groups BH&H--A
Number of projects where change agents play a leading and constructive role in addressing silence and stigma around disability, HIV and--or SRHR in a gender sensitive manner BH&H--A
